chapter.title: Expressions
chapter.para: Ceylon expressions are significantly more flexible than Java, allowing a more declarative style of programming.

listitem.para: literal values, self references, and metamodel references,
callable references and anonymous functions,
invocation of methods and instantiation of classes,
evaluation and assignment of attributes,
comprehensions, and
operators.

chapter.para: Ceylon expressions are validated for typesafety at compile time. To determine whether an expression is assignable to a program element such as an attribute, local, or parameter, Ceylon considers the type of the expression (the type of the objects that are produced when the expression is evaluated). An expression is assignable to a program element if the type of the expression is assignable to the declared type of the program element.

comment.para: TODO: We need a definition of a "constant expression". We might use it for:

comment.para: For example we could follow Java's very restrictive model, and say that a constant expression must be anything formed from literals, metamodel references, the .. and -> operators. Or we could be much less restrictive and just say that it is any expression that could be used to initialize a toplevel attribute of the package.
At the very least, we need to properly define the scope in which the above things are actually evaluated.

section.title: Object instances, identity, and reference passing
section.para: An object is a unique identifier, together with a reference to a class, and a value for each simple attribute of the class (including inherited simple attributes). The object is said to be an instance of the class.

A value is a reference to an object (a copy of its unique identifier). At a particular point in the execution of the program, every attribute of every object that exists, and every initialized local of every method or initializer that is currently executing has a value. Furthermore, every time an expression is executed, it produces a value.

Two values are said to be identical if they are references to the same object—if they hold the same unique identifier. The program may determine if two values of type IdentifiableObject are identical using the &identical; operator. It may not directly obtain the unique identifier (which is a purely abstract construct). The program has no way of determining the identity of a value which is not of type IdentifiableObject.

Invocation of a method or class initializer results in execution of the method with parameter values that are copies of the value produced by executing the argument expressions of the invocation, and a reference to the receiving instance that is a copy of the value produced by executing the receiver expression. The value produced by the invocation expression is a copy of the value produced by execution of the return directive expression.

A new object is produced by execution of a class instantiation expression. The Ceylon compiler guarantees that if execution of a class initializer terminates with no uncaught exception, then every simple attribute of the object has been initialized. The value of an non-variable simple attribute or local is initialized for the first time by execution of a specifier. Every class instantiation expression results in an object with a new unique identifier shared by no other existing object. The object exists from the point at which execution of its initializer terminates. Conceptually, the object exists until execution of the program terminates.

In practice, the object exists at least until the point at which it is not reachable by recursively following references from a local in a method or initializer currently being executed, or from an expression in a statement currently being executed. At this point, its simple attribute values are no longer accessible to expressions which subsequently execute and the object may be destroyed by the virtual machine. There is no way for the program to determine that an object has been destroyed by the virtual machine (unlike Java, Ceylon does not provide object finalizers).
As a special exception to the rules defined above:

listitem.para: The compiler is permitted to emit bytecode that produces a new instance of certain types in the module ceylon.language without execution of the initializer of the class, whenever any expression is evaluated. These types are: any of the the built-in numeric types, Character, Range, Entry, and String. Furthermore, it is permitted to use such a newly-produced instance as the value of the expression, as long as the newly-produced instance is equal to the value expected according to the rules above, as determined using the == operator.

section.para: Therefore, the types listed above directly extend Object or Void instead of IdentifiableObject.

The execution of a Ceylon program complies with the rules laid out by the Java programming language's execution model (Chapter 17 of the Java Language Specification). Ceylon attributes and locals are considered variables in the sense of the JLS. Evaluation is considered a use operation, and assignment is considered an assign operation, again in terms of the JLS.

section.title: Literal values
section.para: Ceylon supports literal values of the following types:

listitem.para: Integer and Float,
Character, and
String, along with
single quoted literals.

section.para: The types Integer, Float, Character, and String are defined in the module ceylon.language.
Ceylon does not need a special syntax for Boolean literal values, since Boolean is just a class with the cases true and false. Likewise, null is just the singleton value of an anonymous class.
section.programlisting: Literal: IntegerLiteral | FloatLiteral | CharacterLiteral | StringLiteral | QuotedLiteral
section.para: All literal values are instances of immutable types. The value of a literal expression is an instance of the type. How this instance is produced is not specified here.

section.title: Integer number literals
section.para: An integer literal n is an expression of type Integer.

section.title: Floating point number literals
section.para: A floating point literal is an expression of type Float.

section.title: Character literals
section.para: A single character literal is an expression of type Character.

section.title: Character string literals
section.para: A character string literal is an expression of type String.

section.title: Single quoted literals
section.para: Single-quoted strings are used to express literal values for dates, times, regexes and hexadecimal numbers, and even for more domain-specific things like names, cron expressions, internet addresses, and phone numbers. This is an important facility since Ceylon is a language for expressing structured data.
section.programlisting: Email { to = 'gavin@hibernate.org'; subject="Ceylon"; text = "Need some help with the compiler?"; }
section.para: A single quoted literal may only appear in the following positions:

listitem.para: as the right hand side of a specifier for a local or attribute with an explicitly declared type, or
as an argument of an invocation or instantiation.

section.para: In either case:

listitem.para: the declared type of the local, attribute, or parameter must be a class or interface annotated literal, and
the single quoted literal must match the pattern specified by the format argument of the literal annotation.

section.para: The type of the literal expression is the declared type of the local, attribute, or parameter. At runtime, an instance of this type is produced by calling the method specified by the parser argument of the literal annotation.

comment.para: TODO: Single quoted operator literals should come built-in. For example: '+' and '<='.
TODO: we should try to support interpolated expressions, just like we do for string literals.

section.title: String templates
section.para: A character string template contains interpolated expressions, surrounded by character string fragments.
An interpolated expression may not begin with a string literal or the unary prefix + operator.
Each interpolated expression contained in the string template must have a type assignable to Object defined in ceylon.language.
section.programlisting: log.info("Hello, " person.firstName " " person.lastName ", the time is " Time() ".");
section.para: An interpolated expression in a string template may invoke or evaluate:

listitem.para: any class member that is visible to the containing scope in which the literal appears, and
any non-variable local, block local attribute getter or block local method declared earlier within the containing scope.

comment.para: TODO: Should string templates be evaluated lazily?

section.title: Self references
section.para: The type of the following expressions depends upon the context in which they appear.

The keyword super refers to the current instance (the instance that is being invoked), and has the same members as the immediate superclass of the class, except for formal
members. Any invocation of this reference is processed by the method or attribute defined or inherited by the superclass, bypassing any method declaration that refines the method on the current class or any subclass of the current class. The super reference is not assignable to any type. Nor may not be narrowed to any type using if (is ...). There is no super reference in an interface member body.

comment.para: TODO: super doesn't let you call a refined member belonging to an interface. A solution would be to let you rename the refined member in an import statement. Another possibility would be to introduce a specialized syntax, for example something like super(Writer).write(string).

section.para: The keyword this refers to the current instance, and is assignable to the type of the current class or interface (the class or interface in which the expression appears).

The keyword outer refers to the current instance of the class or interface which immediately contains the current class or interface and is assignable to the type of this containing class or interface.

section.title: Compound expressions
section.para: An atom is a literal or self reference, an enumeration expression, or a parenthesized expression.
A primary is formed by recursively invoking or evaluating members of an atom, toplevel method, toplevel attribute, or class.
More complex expressions are formed by combining expressions using operators, including assignment operators.
Parentheses are used for grouping:

section.title: Receiver expressions
section.para: A callable reference or value reference may specify a receiver expression. The receiver expression produces the instance upon which a member is invoked or evaluated. The type of the receiver expression must have a member with the specified name.
A receiver expression must be explicitly specified, unless:

listitem.para: the reference is to a toplevel method, toplevel attribute, or class,
the reference is to a local or parameter, or
the current instance of a containing class is the receiver.

section.para: When a callable reference with a receiver expression is executed, the receiver expresson is evaluated and a reference to the resulting value is held as part of the callable reference. When a value reference with a receiver expression is executed, the receiver expression is evaluated and a reference to the resulting value is held as part of the value reference.

section.title: Anonymous functions
section.para: An anonyomous function declaration may occur in a positional argument list, return directive, or specifier. An anonymous function defines a method with no method name. It comprises one or more parameter lists, followed by an expression.

The parameters are the parameters of the method. The expression is the return value of the method, and the type of the expression is the return type of the method, unless the method is explicitly declared using the void keyword.
An anonymous function declaration is treated as an expression. The type of the expression is the callable byte of the method.

section.title: Value references
section.para: A value reference is a reference to something—for example, an attribute, a local, or an invocation expression—that can be evaluated.
A value reference expression is assignable to the type of the attribute or local, or the return type of the invocation expression.

section.title: Attribute and local references
section.para: An attribute reference is a reference to an attribute of some object. A local reference is a reference to a local or parameter. An attribute reference specifies the name of the attribute. A local reference specifies the name of the local or parameter.
The type of an attribute reference or local reference expression for an attribute, local, or parameter of declared type X is simply X.

section.title: Callable references
section.para: A callable reference is a reference to something—a method, callable parameter, or class—that can be invoked by specifying a list of arguments.

A callable reference may be invoked immediately, or it may be passed to other code which may invoke the reference. A callable reference captures the return type and parameter lists of the method, callable parameter, or class it refers to, allowing compile-time validation of argument types when the callable reference is invoked.
A callable reference expression is assignable to Callable<T,P...> where T and P... depend upon the schema of the method or class.

section.title: Type arguments
section.para: If a callable reference expression refers to a generic declaration, either:

listitem.para: it must be immediately followed by an argument list, allowing the compiler to infer the type arguments, or
it must specify an explicit type argument list.

section.title: Method references
section.para: If a callable reference specifies a method name (or callable parameter name), it is called a method reference.
The type of a method reference expression is assignable to the callable type of the method. Calling the method reference results in execution of the method.

section.title: Initializer references
section.para: If a callable reference specifies a class name, it is called an initializer reference.
The type of an initializer reference expression is assignable to the callable type of the class. Calling the initializer reference results in instantiation of the class.

section.title: Callable objects as method implementations
section.para: An expression of type Callable may be used to define a method using =. The expression type must be assignable to the callable type of the method being defined.
section.programlisting: Comparison order<Value>(Value x, Value y) = reverse;
void print<Printable>(Printable printable) given Printable of String | Integer | Float = printer.print;

section.title: Callable objects as callable parameter arguments
section.para: An expression of type Callable may appear as an argument to a callable parameter, either as a positional argument, or as an argument specified using = in a named argument invocation. The expression type must be assignable to the callable type of the callable parameter.
This method has a callable parameter:
section.programlisting: void sort(List<String> list, Comparison by(String x, String y)) { ... }
section.para: This code passes a reference to a local method to the method.
section.programlisting: Comparison reverseAlpha(String x, String y) { return y<=>x; } sort(names, reverseAlpha);
section.para: This class has two callable parameters:
section.programlisting: shared class TextInput(Integer size=30, String onInit(), String onUpdate(String s)) { ... }
section.para: This code instantiates the class, passing references to methods which set and get the attribute person.name:

section.title: Callable objects as method return values
section.para: Calling a method with multiple parameter lists is called partial application of the method.
section.programlisting: Comparison order(Integer x, Integer y) = getOrder(); Comparison comp = order(1,-1);
section.para: This is even simpler using type inference:
section.programlisting: function order(Integer x, Integer y) = getOrder(); value comp = order(1,-1);
section.para: Or, if we don't need parameter names, we don't even need to explicitly declare the parameter list:
section.programlisting: value order = getOrder(); value comp = order(1,-1);
section.para: In this case, order is actually not a method at all—it's just a local of type Callable<Comparison,Integer,Integer>.
Of course, more than one argument list may be specified in a single expression:

section.title: Invocation expressions
section.para: A callable object—any instance of Callable—is invokable. An invocation consists of an invoked expression of type Callable<T,P...>, together with an argument list and, optionally, an explicit type argument list.

Any invocation expression where the invoked expression is a callable reference expression is called a direct invocation expression of the method, callable parameter, or class. In the case of a direct invocation expression, the compiler has additional information about the schema of the method or class that is not reified by the Callable interface. The compiler is aware of:

listitem.para: the names of the parameters of the method or class,
which parameters are defaulted, and their default values, and
whether the last parameter in the list is a sequenced parameter.

section.para: (Furthermore, in the case of a direct invocation expression, type argument inference is possible, since the compiler is aware of the type parameters and constraints of the method or class.)

An invocation expression must specify arguments for parameters of the callable object, either by listing parameter values in order or, in the case of a direct invocation, listing named parameter values.
Arguments to required parameters must be specified.

listitem.para: If the invocation expression is a direct invocation expression, arguments to defaulted parameters may optionally be specified, and one or more arguments to a sequenced parameter may optionally be specified.
Otherwise, an argument must be specified for each defaulted parameter, and a single argument must be specified for the sequenced parameter.

section.para: For a required or defaulted parameter of type T, the type of the corresponding argument expression must be assignable to T.
If the invocation expression is a direct invocation expression, then for a sequenced parameter of type T..., there may be either:

listitem.para: an arbitrary number of argument expressions of type assignable to T, or
a single argument expression of type assignable to T[].

section.para: Otherwise, if the invocation is not a direct invocation expression, then a sequenced parameter of type T... is treated like an ordinary required parameter and an argument to the sequenced parameter is always a single expression of type assignable to T[].

comment.para: TODO: Alternatively, we could have a special type that represents a sequenced parameter, allowing the usual invocation semantics even when it's not a direct invocation expression. String... would be an abbreviation for SequencedArgument<String> and names... would be an abbreviation for SequencedArgument(names).

section.para: For a tuple parameter of psuedo-type P..., the type of the corresponding argument expression must be P.... (That is, it must be a tuple parameter of declared type P....)
The type of an invocation expression is simply R where R is the type argument to the first type parameter of the expression type Callable (the return type).

section.title: Method invocation
section.para: For a method invocation, the invocation expression is of type R where R is the return type of the method. The type of a void method invocation expression is Void.

section.title: Class instantiation
section.para: Invocation of an initializer reference is called instantiation of the class. For a class instantation, the invocation expression is of type T where T is the class.

section.para: An instantiation expression for the type Sequence may be written in an abbreviated form where the type name is eliminated.

The type of a sequence instantiation expression is:

itemizedlist.listitem: Empty if there are no argument expressions, or
Sequence<X|Y|Z...> where X, Y, Z are the types of the argument expressions, otherwise.

section.title: Positional arguments
section.para: When arguments are listed, the arguments list is enclosed in parentheses.
Positional arguments must be listed in the same order as the corresponding parameters.

listitem.para: First, an argument of each required parameters must be specified, in the order in which the required parameters were declared. There must be at least as many arguments as required parameters.

Next, arguments of the first arbitrary number of defaulted parameters may be specified, in the order in which the defaulted parameters were declared. If there are fewer arguments than defaulted parameters, the remaining defaulted parameters are assigned their default values.
Finally, if arguments to all defaulted parameters have been specified, and if the method declares a sequenced parameter, an arbitrary number of arguments to the sequenced parameter may be specified.

section.title: Named arguments
section.para: When arguments are named, the argument list is enclosed in braces.
Named arguments may be listed in a different order to the corresponding parameters.
Required and defaulted parameter arguments are specified by name. Arguments to a sequenced parameter are specified by listing them, without specifying a name, at the end of the argument list.
A named argument is either:

listitem.para: a specification statement where the name of the value being specified is the parameter name—it specifies its value using =, followed by an expression, and is terminated by a semicolon, or

a local declaration with a getter or named argument list where the name of the local is the parameter name—it specifies the type of the attribute or value, and a block or code or named argument list used to instantiate the return type, or
a local anonymous class declaration where the name of the local is the parameter name—an object declaration, or

only for callable parameters, a local method declaration with a block or named parameter list where the name of the method is the parameter name—it specifies the return type or function, a parameter list and a block of code or named argument list used to instantiate the return type.

section.title: Sequenced and tuple arguments
section.para: For a sequenced parameter of type T... in a direct invocation expression, there may be either:

listitem.para: multiple arguments separated by commas, or
a single argument followed by an ellipsis.

section.para: In the first case, the argument expressions are evaluated and collected into an instance of Iterable<T> when the invocation is executed.
In the second case, the single argument expression must be of type Iterable<T>, and must be followed by an ellipsis ..., to indicate that it is not necessary to wrap the value in an Iterable.
An argument to a tuple parameter is always a single expression followed by an ellipsis.

comment.para: Note: the ellipsis ... is like the opposite of a sequence instantiation: { x... } means x and { x, y }... means x, y.

section.title: Default arguments
section.para: When no argument is assigned to a defaulted parameter by the caller, the default argument defined by the parameter declaration is used. The default argument expression is evaluated every time the method is invoked with no argument specified for the defaulted parameter.

section.title: Evaluation, invocation, and assignment
section.para: Evaluation of an expression may result in:

listitem.para: invocation of a method or instantiation of a class,
evaluation of an attribute or local, or
assignment to a variable attribute or local.

section.title: Evaluation
section.para: Evaluation of an attribute reference or local reference produces the current value of the attribute or local.
When a local evaluation is executed, the current value of the local is immediately obtained. The resulting value is the current value of the local.
When an attribute evaluation is executed:

listitem.para: first, the reference expression is executed to obtain the reference object, then
the actual member to be invoked is determined by considering the runtime type of the receiving instance, and then
if the member is a simple attribute, the current value of the simple attribute is retrieved from the recieving instance, or
otherwise, execution of the calling context pauses while the body of the attribute getter is executed by the receiving instance, then,
finally, when execution of the getter ends without a thrown exception, execution of the calling context resumes.

section.para: The resulting value is the current value of the simple attribute or the return value of the attribute getter, as specified by the return directive.

section.title: Invocation
section.para: Evaluation of an invocation expression of a callable reference invokes the underlying callable reference. This is called invocation in the case of a method reference, and instantiation in the case of an initializer reference.
When an evaluation of an invocation expression of a callable reference is executed:

listitem.para: first, the invoked expression is executed to obtain the callable object, then
each argument is evaluated in turn in the calling context, then
the actual member to be invoked is determined by considering the runtime type of the receiving instance and the static types of the arguments, and then
execution of the calling context pauses while the body of the method or initializer is executed by the receiving instance with the argument values, then
finally, when execution of the method or initializer ends without a thrown exception, execution of the calling context resumes.

section.para: A method invocation evaluates to the return value of the method, as specified by the return directive. The argument values are passed to the parameters of the method, and the body of the method is executed.

The actual value that invocation of a void method returns is not specified here. The type system and the definition of the is operator ensures that a value of type Void can never be narrowed to a more specific type.
A class instantiation evaluates to a new instance of the class. The argument values are passed to the initializer parameters of the class, and the initializer is executed.

section.title: Assignment
section.para: The assignment operator := assigns a new value to an attribute reference for a variable attribute or local.
When an attribute or local is assigned:

listitem.para: first, the reference expression is executed to obtain the reference object, then
the actual member to be invoked is determined by considering the runtime type of the receiving instance, and then
if the member is a simple attribute or local, the value of the simple attribute of local is set to the new value,
otherwise, execution of the calling context pauses while the body of the attribute setter is executed by the receiving instance with the new value, then,
finally, when execution of the setter ends without a thrown exception, execution of the calling context resumes.

section.title: Metamodel references
section.para: The metamodel object representing a type or program element may be obtained using a completely typesafe syntax.
section.programlisting: Meta: TypeMeta | MethodMeta | AttributeMeta | FunctionMeta | ValueMeta
section.para: Metamodel references are compile-time typesafe.
A metamodel reference that refers to a generic declaration must specify type arguments.

comment.para: Note: this restriction results from the lack of existential types. The expression Entry would have the existential type ClassConstructor<Entry<Key,Item>,Key,Item> given Key satisfies Object given Item satisfies Object. The expression Comparable.smallerThan would be of existential type MethodConstructor<Value,Boolean,Value> given Value satisfies Comparable<Value>.

TODO: Do we anyway need some kind of metamodel objects for type constructors like Entry or even Comparable.smallerThan. These would not support typesafe operations, but would at least allow runtime reflection.
TODO: Are there metamodel objects for block local declarations? This includes block local declarations inside a class body, and block local declarations inside a method or attribute body.
TODO: Should we have typesafe metamodel reference expressions for parameters? For example: Parameter<String> wordsParam = Person.say#words;

section.title: Interface and class metamodel references
section.para: A Type object may be obtained by specifying the full type, including type arguments if the type is generic.
The metamodel expression, X, for a type, class or interface is:

listitem.para: of type Interface<X> where X is the interface, or
assignable to Class<X,P...> where X is the toplevel abstract class and P... are the types of the parameter list of the class, or
assignable to OpenConcreteClass<X,P...> where X is the toplevel concrete class and P... are the types of the parameter list of the class, or
assignable to OpenMemberClass<X,Y,P...> where Y is the member class and P... are the types of the parameter list of the class.

section.para: Note that for a toplevel class X, the expression X is both a metamodel reference and a callable reference. This is consistent, since Class<X,P...> is a subtype of Callable<X,P...>.

Furthermore, the expression type is assignable to all metatypes of the type—the types listed in the is clause of the type definition. (Note that metatypes are a proposed feature for a future version of the language.)

section.title: Toplevel method metamodel references
section.para: A Function object representing a toplevel method may be obtained by specifying the method name, with type arguments if the toplevel method is generic.
The metamodel expression, method, for a toplevel method is:

listitem.para: assignable to OpenFunction<R,P...> where R is the callable type of a method produced by removing the first parameter list of the method, and P... are the types of the first parameter lists of the method.

section.para: Note that for a toplevel method x(), the expression x is both a metamodel reference and a callable reference. This is consistent, since Function<X,P...> is a subtype of Callable<X,P...>.

section.title: Member method metamodel references
section.para: A Method object representing a member method may be obtained by specifying the type (with type arguments) and member name, together with type arguments if the method is generic.
The metamodel expression, X.member, for a member method is:

listitem.para: assignable to OpenMethod<X,R,P...> where X is the type that defines the method, and R is the callable type of a method produced by removing the first parameter list of the method, and P... are the types of the first parameter list of the method.

section.title: Toplevel attribute metamodel references
section.para: A Value object representing a toplevel attribute may be obtained by specifying the attribute name, with type arguments if the toplevel method is generic.
The metamodel expression, attribute, for a toplevel attribute is:

listitem.para: of type OpenValue<T> where T is the declared type of the attribute.

section.para: Note that for a toplevel attribute x, the expression x is both a metamodel reference and a value reference. This is consistent, since Value<T> is assignable to Gettable<T>.

section.title: Member attribute metamodel references
section.para: An Attribute object representing a member attribute may be obtained by specifying the type (with type arguments) and member name.
The metamodel expression, X.member, for a member attribute is:

listitem.para: of type OpenAttribute<X,T> where X is the type that defines the attribute, and T is the declared type of the attribute, unless the attribute is declared variable, or
of type OpenMutableAttribute<X,T> where X is the type that defines the attribute, and T is the declared type of the attribute, if the attribute is declared variable.

section.title: Using the metamodel
section.para: The metamodel object for a type allows its members to be iterated:
The metamodel object for a class, attribute or method satisfies Callable and is therefore invokable.
section.programlisting:
Class<ArrayList<String>,String[]> arrayListClass = ArrayList<String>;
List list = arrayListClass("foo", "bar", "baz);

Attribute<Person, String> nameAttribute = Person.name;
String personName = nameAttribute(person);

Method<Person, String> sayMethod = Person.say;
String result = sayMethod(person)();
section.para: The metamodel object for a class, attribute or method supports registration of a listener, which intercepts invocations.

section.title: Operators
section.para: Operators are syntactic shorthand for more complex expressions involving method invocation or attribute access. Each operator is defined for a particular type. There is no support for user-defined operator overloading. However, the semantics of an operator may be customized by the implementation of the type that the operator applies to. This is called operator polymorphism.
Some examples:

In all operator expressions, the arguments of the operator must be evaluated from left to right when the expression is executed. In certain cases, depending upon the definition of the operator, evaluation of the leftmost argument expression results in a value that causes the final value of the operator expression to be produced immediately without evaluation of the remaining argument expressions. Optimizations performed by the Ceylon compiler must not alter these behaviours.

comment.para: TODO: Should we have operators for function composition, or even partial application. Perhaps infix : could be composition and postfix @ could be partial application.

section.title: Operator expressions
section.para: The type of an operator expression for an operator that is defined to produce the type T is:

listitem.para: T, if T is assignable to Gettable<Object>, or, otherwise,
Gettable<T>.

section.title: Operator precedence
section.para: There are 16 distinct operator precedence levels, but these levels are arranged into layers in order to make them easier to predict.

listitem.para: Operators in layer 1 produce, transform, and combine values.
Operators in layer 2 compare or predicate values, producing a Boolean result.
Operators in layer 3 are logical operators that operate upon Boolean arguments to produce a Boolean value.
Operators in layer 4 perform assignment and conditional evaluation.

section.para: Within each layer, postfix operators have a higher precedence than prefix operators, and prefix operators have a higher precedence than binary operators.

section.title: Operator definition
section.para: The following tables define the semantics of the Ceylon operators. There are four basic operators which do not have a definition in terms of other operators or invocations:

listitem.para: the member selection operator . separates the receiver expression and member name in a callable reference expression or attribute reference expression,
the argument specification operators () and {} specify the argument list of an invocation,
the assignment operator := assigns a new value to an instance of Settable and returns the new value after assignment,
the assignability operator is evaluates to true if its argument expression evaluates to an instance of a class assignable to the specified type, and false otherwise.

section.para: All other operators are defined in terms of other operators and/or invocations.

section.title: Arithmetic operators
section.para: These are the usual mathematical operations for all kinds of numeric values.
Ceylon's numeric type system is designed to accommodate the following considerations:

listitem.para: The system is extensible and new numeric types may be defined by libraries. Numeric types defined by libraries should work the same as built-in numeric types.
implicit type conversions should never lose information and
binary operators must be symmetric.
Furthermore, there should be no special cases in the language definition or type checker to accommodate numeric types.
However, it must be possible for the compiler to optimize certain of the built-in numeric types to take advantage of the VM's native support for numeric types.

It is not necessary to encode information about the limits of the machine's representation of a numeric value into the type system. A single Integer class is sufficient to represent 32, 64, or 128 bit integer values. A single Float class is sufficient to represent single and double precision floating point values. It is simply not possible for the compiler to detect numeric overflow or loss of significant precision.
